sections.body: Water is both a great enabler and great destroyer of civilization. Life can't exist without it. Trade and travel are made much easier by its presence. Yet water can also kill, from drowning on a personal level to floods and tsunamis on a mass scale. Terrestrial life is dependent on water but at the same time fears it, as evidenced by tales as old as the sea itself, of monsters and the hideous fates that await travelers who dare to sail out of sight of land. What better place to set an adventure than on a twisting river, upon the high seas, or deep in the briny world below?
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Water
sections.name: Water

sections.body: An aquatic adventure can take place anywhere that water is the primary terrain feature. This includes marshlands, rivers, lakes, pools, oceans, the Plane of Water, and the like. Aquatic adventures don't require the PCs to have the ability to breathe water, of course—the inclusion of water hazards for lower-level adventurers to navigate can add a nice bit of suspense and peril to an adventure.
sections.name: Aquatic Adventures
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Aquatic Adventures

sections.body: The rules presented in the Pathfinder RPG Core Rulebook for underwater combat apply to creatures not native to this dangerous environment, such as most PCs. For extended aquatic adventures or for particularly deep explorations, PCs will doubtless need to use magic to continue their adventures. Water breathing is of obvious use, while endure elements can help with temperature. Pressure damage can be avoided entirely with effects such as freedom of movement. Polymorph spells are perhaps the most useful in water, though, if the form assumed is aquatic in nature.
sections.name: Adapting to Aquatic Environments
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Aquatic Adventures/Adapting to Aquatic Environments

sections.body: Any creature that has the aquatic subtype can breathe water easily and is unaffected by water temperature extremes that are found in that creature's typical environment. Aquatic creatures and creatures with the hold breath ability are much more resistant to pressure damage; they do not suffer damage from pressure unless they are moved instantaneously from one depth to another in the blink of an eye (in which case they adapt to the pressure change after successfully making five successive Fortitude saves against the pressure effects).
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Aquatic Adventures/Adapting to Aquatic Environments/Natural Adaptation
sections.name: Natural Adaptation

sections.body: Water can also provide the setting for a different and unique game experience—the nautical adventure. In such a scenario, the effects and dangers of underwater adventuring are replaced by surface hazards as the PCs and their opponents use vehicles like ships and boats to navigate the terrain. For the most part, shipboard adventures can be resolved normally, with a combat taking place aboard a ship functioning almost identically to one that occurs on land. If the combat happens during a storm or in heavy seas, treat the ship's deck as difficult terrain. Remember to take into account the effects on spellcasters' concentration checks due to weather or the motion of the ship's deck (Pathfinder RPG Core Rulebook 206–207).
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Nautical Adventures
sections.name: Nautical Adventures

sections.body: When ships themselves become a part of a combat, things get more unusual. The following rules are not meant to accurately simulate all of the complexities of ship-to-ship combat, only to provide you with a quick and easy set of rules to resolve such situations when they inevitably arise in a nautical adventure, whether it be a battle between two ships or between a ship and a sea monster.
sections.name: Fast-Play Ship Combat
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Fast-Play Ship Combat

sections.body: Decide what type of ships are involved in the combat (see Table 7–49: Ship Statistics). Use a large, blank battle mat to represent the waters on which the battle occurs. A single square corresponds to 30 feet of distance. Represent each ship by placing markers that take up the appropriate number of squares (miniature toy ships make great markers and should be available at most hobby stores).
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Fast-Play Ship Combat/Preparation
sections.name: Preparation

sections.body: When combat begins, allow the PCs (and important NPC allies) to roll initiative as normal—the ship itself moves and attacks on the captain's initiative result. If any of the ships in the battle rely on sails to move, randomly determine what direction the wind is blowing by rolling 1d8 and following the guidelines for missed splash weapons (Core Rulebook 202).
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Fast-Play Ship Combat/Starting Combat
sections.name: Starting Combat

sections.body: On the captain's initiative count, the ship can move its current speed in a single round as a move-equivalent action for the captain (or double its speed as a full-round action), as long as it has its minimum crew complement. The ship can increase or decrease its speed by 30 feet each round, up to its maximum speed. Alternatively, the captain can change direction (up to one side of a square at a time) as a standard action. A ship can only change direction at the start of a turn.
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Fast-Play Ship Combat/Movement
sections.name: Movement

sections.body:
Crewmembers in excess of the ship's minimum crew requirement can be allocated to man siege engines. Siege engines attack on the captain's initiative count.

A ship can also attempt to ram a target if it has its minimum crew. To ram a target, the ship must move at least 30 feet and end with its bow in a square adjacent to the target. The ship's captain then makes a Profession (sailor) check—if this check equals or exceeds the target's AC, the ship hits its target, inflicting damage as indicated on the ship statistics table to the target, as well as minimum damage to the ramming ship. A ship outfitted with an actual ram siege engine inflicts an additional 3d6 points of damage to the target (the ramming vessel suffers no additional damage).
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Fast-Play Ship Combat/Attacks
sections.name: Attacks

sections.body: A ship gains the sinking condition if its hit points are reduced to 0 or fewer. A sinking ship cannot move or attack, and it sinks completely 10 rounds after it gains the sinking condition. Each hit on a sinking ship that inflicts damage reduces the remaining time for it to sink by 1 round per 25 points of damage inflicted. Magic (such as make whole) can repair a sinking ship if the ship's hit points are raised above 0, at which point the ship loses the sinking condition. Generally, nonmagical repairs take too long to save a ship from sinking once it begins to go down.
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Fast-Play Ship Combat/Sinking
sections.name: Sinking

sections.body: A vast variety of boats and ships exist in the real world, from small rafts and longboats to intimidating galleons and swift galleys. To represent the numerous distinctions of shape and size that exist between water-going vessels, Table 7–49 categorizes seven standard ship sizes and their respective statistics. Just as the cultures of the real world have created and adapted hundreds of different types of seafaring vessels, races in fantasy worlds might create their own strange ships. GMs might use or alter the statistic above to suit the needs of their creations, and describe such conveyances however they please. All ships have the following traits.
sections.name: Ship Statistics
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Fast-Play Ship Combat/Ship Statistics

sections.body: This is a general category that lists the ship's basic type.
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Fast-Play Ship Combat/Ship Statistics/Ship Type
sections.name: Ship Type

sections.body: The ship's base Armor Class. To calculate a ship's actual AC, add the captain's Profession (sailor) modifier to the ship's base AC. Touch attacks against a ship ignore the captain's modifier. A ship is never considered flat-footed.
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Fast-Play Ship Combat/Ship Statistics/AC
sections.name: AC

sections.body: The ship's total hit points. In addition, all ships have a hardness rating based on their construction material (hardness 5 for most wooden ships). At 0 or fewer hit points, a ship gains the sinking condition as described above.
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Fast-Play Ship Combat/Ship Statistics/hp
sections.name: hp

sections.body: The ship's base save modifier. All of a ship's saving throws (Fortitude, Reflex, and Will) have the same value. To determine a ship's actual saving throw modifiers, add the captain's Profession (sailor) modifier to this base value.
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Fast-Play Ship Combat/Ship Statistics/Base Save
sections.name: Base Save

sections.body: The ship's maximum tactical speed in combat. An asterisk indicates the ship has sails, and can move at double speed when it moves in the same direction as the wind. A ship with only sails can only move if there is some wind.
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Fast-Play Ship Combat/Ship Statistics/Maximum Speed
sections.name: Maximum Speed

sections.body: The number of siege engines (Core Rulebook 434–436) that can be fitted on the ship. A ram uses one of these slots, and only one ram may be fitted to a ship.
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Fast-Play Ship Combat/Ship Statistics/Arms
sections.name: Arms

sections.body: The amount of damage the ship inflicts on a successful ramming attack (without a ram siege engine).
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Fast-Play Ship Combat/Ship Statistics/Ram
sections.name: Ram

sections.body: The number of squares the ship takes up on the battle mat. A ship's width is always considered to be one square.
sections.url: pfsrd://Game Mastery Guide/Rules/Fast Play Ship Combat/Fast-Play Ship Combat/Ship Statistics/Squares
sections.name: Squares

sections.body: The first number lists the minimum crew complement the ship needs to function normally, excluding those needed to make use of the vessel's weapons. The second value lists the ship's maximum crew plus additional soldiers or passengers. A ship without its minimum crew complement can only move, change speed, change direction, or ram if its captain makes a DC 20 Profession (sailor) check. Crew in excess of the minimum have no effect on movement, but they can replace fallen crewmembers or man additional weapons.
